titlestmt.titleproper:
Guide to the Harold Holzer Collection of Lincolniana
1860-1939
PR 402
titlestmt.author: Joseph Ditta

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2023-08-21 15:48:44 -0400.

did.abstract: Approximately 36 prints of Abraham Lincoln, Jefferson Davis, Robert E. Lee, and Mary Anna Randolph Custis Lee assembled by Lincoln scholar Harold Holzer.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Harold Holzer Collection of Lincolniana is organized in five series:

defitem.label: Series I.
defitem.item: Ephemera relating to Jefferson Davis and Robert E. Lee, circa 1862-1889, undated

defitem.label: Series II.
defitem.item: Engravings of Lincoln from the campaign period, 1860

defitem.label: Series IV.
defitem.item: Prints issued after Lincoln's death, 1866-1898, undated

defitem.label: Series V.
defitem.item: Prints of Lincoln from the late 19th and early 20th centuries, 1899-1939, undated

arrangement.p: This material was offered, but went unsold, in Swann Auction Galleries sale 2486, "Printed & Manuscript Americana Featuring the Holzer Collection of Lincolniana," on September 27, 2018. Series I corresponds to Swann lot 40; Series II to lot 95; Series III to lots 133 and 144; Series IV to lot 145; and Series V to lot 148. For details, see the auction catalog.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Harold Holzer (born 1949), longtime administrator at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, and later director of Hunter College's Roosevelt House Public Policy Institute, purchased his first piece of Lincolniana when barely out of his teens. At twenty-two he began focusing on collecting engravings and lithographs of Lincoln. Originally he sought evocative imagery with which to decorate his home, but the materials inspired a lifelong scholarly inquiry that has resulted in over forty books on Lincoln and the Civil War. (See www.haroldholzer.com.)

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Open to qualified researchers by appointment only.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: Permission to reproduce any Department of Prints, Photographs and Architectural Collections holdings through publication must be obtained from: Rights and Reproductions, The New-York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West, New York, NY 10024. Phone: (212) 873-3400 ext. 270. Fax: (212) 579-8794.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Harold Holzer, 2018 (accession no. PPAC.2018.067).

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: This item should be cited as the "Harold Holzer Collection of Lincolniana, PR 402, Department of Prints, Photographs, and Architectural Collections, The New-York Historical Society."

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Archivist Joseph Ditta arranged and described this collection in August 2019.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Aside from a few portraits of Jefferson Davis, Robert E. Lee, and Mary Anna Randolph Custis Lee, this collection is focused on imagery of Abraham Lincoln (including two of his Springfield, Illinois home) created during his lifetime (e.g., the campaign period, 1860), in response to his death, and later in the 19th- and through the mid-20th century.

controlaccess.persname: Lee, Robert E. (Robert Edward), 1807-1870 -- Pictorial works

did.unittitle: Series I. Ephemera relating to Jefferson Davis and Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Uncredited engraving in blue and red depicting Jefferson Davis.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Confederate currency in one, ten, and fifty dollar denominations, the latter bill with a portrait of Jefferson Davis.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Engraving by "Illman Brothers from a photograph taken a few months before his death" above facsimile signature.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Hand-colored engraving clipped from an unidentified (probably British) periodical captioned "The Civil War in America: General Lee, Commander of the Confederate Army in Northern Virginia.--From a sketch by our special artist," February 14, 1863, with a black-and-white version of the same image as published in Harper's Weekly, March 14, 1863, with the caption "The Rebel General R. E. Lee.--From a late drawing by Mr. Vizetelly."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Two engraved portraits of Robert E. Lee clipped from publications, possibly Harper's Weekly or Frank Leslie's.

did.unittitle: Prospectus for Genealogical History of the Lee Family, of Virginia and Maryland, from A.D. 1200 to 1866

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Edward C. Mead's Genealogical History of the Lee Family, of Virginia and Maryland, from A.D. 1200 to 1866 was issued by the University Publishing Company, New York, in 1871.

did.unittitle: Portrait of Robert E. Lee (2 versions)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Plate from Edward C. Mead's Genealogical History of the Lee Family, of Virginia and Maryland, from A.D. 1200 to 1866 (New York: University Publishing Company, 1871). This and the corresponding portrait of Mary Anna Randolph Custis Lee (Box 1, Folder 8) were displayed in the 1987-88 traveling exhibition "The Confederate Image."

did.unittitle: Portrait of Mary Anna Randolph Custis Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Plate from Edward C. Mead's Genealogical History of the Lee Family, of Virginia and Maryland, from A.D. 1200 to 1866 (New York: University Publishing Company, 1871). This and the corresponding portrait of Robert E. Lee (Box 1, Folder 7) were displayed in the 1987-88 traveling exhibition "The Confederate Image."

did.unittitle: Series II. Engravings of Lincoln from the campaign period

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Two examples, one on tinted chine-coll√©.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Uncredited, but apparently pirated lithograph of the Charles Barry campaign print.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Engraved by J. C. Buttre after a photograph by Matthew Brady.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Engraved by J. C. Buttre after a photograph by Matthew Brady.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Published by Benj. B. Russell, Boston.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Unattributed hand-colored engraving.

did.unittitle: Series III. Memorial prints of Lincoln

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Framed, woven silk portrait of Lincoln.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Engraving featuring Lincoln's head on Andrew Jackson's body. Published in New York, late 19th century.

did.unittitle: Series IV. Prints issued after Lincoln's death

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Untitled chromolithograph portrait of Lincoln. Published in Chicago, late 19th century.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Published by Ticknor & Fields, Boston, 1866.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Small untitled imitation of the Marshall engraving, in an oval frame.

did.unittitle: Rees. "Abraham Lincoln's Return Home After His Successful Campaign for the Presidency of the United States, in October, 1860"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Colored lithograph published by Rees Print & Litho Co., Omaha, Nebraska.

did.unittitle: Series V. Prints of Lincoln from the late 19th and early 20th centuries
Ruth Witzel Bilane (1915-2007) after the Marshall print. [Abraham Lincoln]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Signed by the artist in pencil, Union, New Jersey.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Untitled engraving printed by Helen Fagg.

did.unittitle: After Hesler. "Abraham Lincoln as he Appeared Directly after his Nomination in 1860"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Gravure of Hesler photograph, published by H. C. Brown & Co., New York.

did.unittitle: Rea, after Deigendesch. "Lincoln: He was a Type of the True Elder Race"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Engraving published by McCaskey, Lancaster, Pennsylvania.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: "Alexander Gardner's Photograph Gallery, Washington, D. C. Here President Lincoln sat for some portraits. Collection of the Public Library of the District of Columbia."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: "Brady's Studio, Washington, D.C., where President Lincoln sat for some photographic portraits. Collection of L. C. Handy Studios, Washington, D.C."

did.unittitle: Bernhardt Wall. "Cooper Union, New York City"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: "Cooper Union, New York City, where Lincoln made his great speech, Monday evening, Feb. 27, 1860. He was escorted by William Cullen Bryant and David Dudley Field. Collection of New-York Historical Society."

did.unittitle: Bernhardt Wall. "Lincoln and James A. Briggs attended Plymouth Church"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: "Lincoln and James A. Briggs attended Plymouth Church, Brooklyn, to hear Henry W. Beecher preach, March 11, 1860. Collection of New-York Historical Society."

did.unittitle: Bernhardt Wall. "Lincoln, for the first time saw a printing press"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: "Lincoln, for the first time saw a printing press at the Western Sun, or The Indiana Gazette, now The Vincennes Sun, as he was passing thru in March 1830."
